This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

>>14401747
Pope Benedict XVI (German: Benedikt XVI.; born Joseph Aloisius Ratzinger, German; 16 April 1927 - 31 December 2022) was a prelate of the Catholic Church who served as the head of the Church and the sovereign of the Vatican City State from 19 April 2005 until his resignation on 28 February 2013. Benedict's election as pope occurred in the 2005 papal conclave that followed the death of Pope John Paul II. Benedict chose to be known by the title "pope emeritus" upon his resignation. Ordained as a priest in 1951 in his native Bavaria, Ratzinger embarked on an academic career and established himself as a highly regarded theologian by the late 1950s. He was appointed a full professor in 1958 at the age of 31. After a long career as a professor of theology at several German universities, he was appointed Archbishop of Munich and Freising and created a cardinal by Pope Paul VI in 1977, an unusual promotion for someone with little pastoral experience. In 1981, he was appointed Prefect of the Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith, one of the most important dicasteries of the Roman Curia. From 2002 until his election as pope, he was also Dean of the College of Cardinals. Prior to becoming pope, he was "a major figure on the Vatican stage for a quarter of a century"; he had an influence "second to none when it came to setting church priorities and directions" as one of John Paul II's closest confidants. He lived in Rome from 1981 until his death in 2022. His prolific writings generally defend traditional Catholic doctrine and values. He was originally a liberal theologian, but adopted conservative views after 1968. During his papacy, Benedict XVI advocated a return to fundamental Christian values to counter the increased secularisation of many Western countries.

>>14400986
the Iberomaurusian specimens are the ones bearing a very high level of basal Eurasian lineage, which could have been contributed by the sub-Saharan African input added by the southwest Asian founder group, which moved to North Africa 20 ka bearing a high basal Eurasian component. It is interesting that the current-day southwest Asian populations that show more genetic sharing with Iberomaurusians are the east AP populations. We tried to disentangle between an ancient link and a bias due to recent sub-Saharan input in this signature by performing the haplotype-based clustering, and confirmed a still high proportion of the basal Eurasian lineage/Iberomaurusian founding effect in clusters D (east AP and Iran) and F (west AP). Probably, the Iberomaurusian specimens are currently the best proxy for the basal Eurasian population group.
https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2021.02.24.432678v1.full

There's morals and then there's "morals". Classical morals, stuff that nearly all of humanity agrees is bad, like murder, rape, theft, etc hardly need laws in place to make them illegal. Most people wouldn't tolerate it regardless. But once you move away from these universal crimes it quickly becomes a matter of opinion what is good or bad. Like doing drugs. Some people abhor drugs, others use them for fun. Some people believe sex outside of marriage is a sin, others don't have any problem with it. And the list goes on.

So rather than having a legal system where any dogmatic, obsessive lunatic can enforce their "morals" on others, it's better to have a system where, outside the major crimes everybody agrees are bad, the rest of it is just left to people to resolve among themselves without the government making laws against this or that.

>>14391974
Is there truth? I think there probably is because I believe there's an objective universe, based on my observations. I could be wrong though. Due to the problem of induction, I reckon we can't be truly certain of anything. We just have to make our best guesses at knowledge.

>but what about a priori knowledge?
"All bachelors are unmarried men"... you might say that's a priori true, and as such is not subject to the problem of induction. But what if, in 100 years' time, the meaning of the word "bachelor" has changed? What if ends up including women too? (Like the word "actor" is now used for women as well.) So really I think all knowledge is empirical, including the definition of the word "bachelor".

Also think about "2 + 2 = 4". That won't be true anymore if the meaning of "4" changes. But also, I would argue that "2 + 2 = 4" expresses an observation about the universe. It could be that adding two pairs of things caused a fifth thing to pop into existence. Then "2 + 2 = 5" would be true. But that isn't the case. So we're expressing empirical knowledge when we say "2 + 2 = 4".

Atheism and religions are different classes of objects. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Well, what's the alternative? Holy scripture is a piece (or multiple pieces) of language and as such needs human interpretation. Even the most hardcore historicist literalist (ofc KJV only so stuff like problems of translation and the size of the biblical canon can be ignored) will either at one point or the other have to ask himself "wtf does that even mean" or just shrug it off so it becomes totally meaningless dead scripture.

Take something like the genealogies of tribes or the measurements of the temple, why should a literalist care about any of that today? From their point of view, god is talking about things in the past that happened long ago, but the moment they ask the question "and what does that have to do with me?" they start to interpret. Or think about the classic example, the agreements between Mark, Luke and Matthew. When you discover that whole passages are pretty much copy-pasted, your natural reaction is to ask yourself why that is. The Bible itself doesn't tell you "oh btw I gave you three almost identical versions so you could see the same out of different perspectives" or "oh yeah I say it three times to proof it really happened exactly like this", so even the historicist literalist has to come up with SOMETHING or end up just ignoring it away.

Biblical criticism is one method to get an understanding out of biblical text. Yes, there's a lot of guesswork and overanalyzing involved, especially if it's done in a shitty way or with a certain agenda. There are other ways to interpret scripture as well, sometimes they can work pretty well in a complementary way, depending on what you're trying to do or find out. But shitting on biblical criticism just because it appears to be downplaying stuff by contextualizing it doesn't help you in your endeavour of trying to make sense out of scripture.

There were many reasons why Irish troops were enthusiastic to fight for US armies-whether Union or Confederate, but two of the main ones are:
>Citizenship/Respect
Irish people were not respected or well treated in the US, unsurprisingly; they arrived in droves as often monolingual impoverished and unskilled tenant farm labourers, with little to offer to urban centres on the East Coast. Military service was one fairly reliable path to "integration" or "acceptance" as Americans. Irish leaders in the Army were capitalised on by the US to take advantage of the Irish manpower pool, as was the case with Michael Corcoran and the 69th.
>Republican Tricks
Irish Revolutionary leaders encouraged their followers to enlist to gain military experience to be later used against Britain, as we saw in the Fenian Raids.

The US Civil War wasn't really about religion, and by this stage Irish Nationalism and Nationhood had an almost century old tradition of religious unity (United Irishmen, etc). So there wasn't too many reasons not to fight, in all honesty.

Reminder that Saint Joan was more of a man than Nietzsche ever was

> "Joan of Arc was not stuck at the cross-roads, either by rejecting all the paths like Tolstoy, or by accepting them all like Nietzsche. She chose a path, and went down it like a thunderbolt. Yet Joan, when I came to think of her, had in her all that was true either in Tolstoy or Nietzsche, all that was even tolerable in either of them. I thought of all that is noble in Tolstoy, the pleasure in plain things, especially in plain pity, the actualities of the earth, the reverence for the poor, the dignity of the bowed back. Joan of Arc had all that and with this great addition, that she endured poverty as well as admiring it; whereas Tolstoy is only a typical aristocrat trying to find out its secret. And then I thought of all that was brave and proud and pathetic in poor Nietzsche, and his mutiny against the emptiness and timidity of our time. I thought of his cry for the ecstatic equilibrium of danger, his hunger for the rush of great horses, his cry to arms. Well, Joan of Arc had all that, and again with this difference, that she did not praise fighting, but fought. We know that she was not afraid of an army, while Nietzsche, for all we know, was afraid of a cow. Tolstoy only praised the peasant; she was the peasant. Nietzsche only praised the warrior; she was the warrior. She beat them both at their own antagonistic ideals; she was more gentle than the one, more violent than the other. Yet she was a perfectly practical person who did something, while they are wild speculators who do nothing. It was impossible that the thought should not cross my mind that she and her faith had perhaps some secret of moral unity and utility that has been lost. And with that thought came a larger one, and the colossal figure of her Master had also crossed the theatre of my thoughts."

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
So, back to Ford. Ford was by then a large mature company helping dismantle America's defunct, outdated and unwanted railroad network. Ford, and the rest of the auto industry, were building the World Of Tomorrow they promised in 1933. With the core Interstate network built out, cars were faster than ever and millions of Americans were liberated economically as they could live and work wherever they wanted. Gas was nickles to the gallon and some of the fastest road cars ever built would soon be released to the public. With such massive domestic success, it was only natural to pave the entire planet in freeways. It's certainly why American companies like Esso and Union Carbide were in Vietnam - they wanted their oil, their minerals, and their labor to produce car parts in an increasingly globalized market just as they did with Brazil vis-a-vis rubber tires thirty years prior. New plastics meant a whole new world of manufacturing was plausible, requiring new machines. Chief amongst these were the Bradley IFV/M113 (which is now being replaced with the OMFV/M1284 due to the Ukraine War) and the M-16, which came to symbolize the war's failures as early models were prone to cracking and breaking under stress.

I mention this because the other side of the war was the nationbuilding in the locomotives, trucks, power plants and other miscellany we sent to Vietnam as we also sent to Korea, Japan and West Germany. It was around ~1960 where American companies bothered to keep records of this stuff, and cameras had become cheap enough where records of such things could exist. And this was also how the war came home through television and newspapers, similar to the civil rights debate. This latter part matters because the people in charge could not account for the public's response to such visceral, real images of war, and this gradually annhilated the Nixon adminsitration when he failed to get us out as he promised. Which relates to the growing domestic peace movement.

Field generals need to possess a few traits, among others:

>>14392118
>For example, the US had vastly superior systems of supply for most of its wars against gorillas
To add to the guy who said wars were won mostly by will and logistics we need to add another important variable, which is strategy. If one has declared war against something like "terror," or if one has poorly defined or impossible goals, then they have severely burdened their fighting force.

Consequently, the reason why a weaker side might still fight a war is because their war goals could be completely different, time might be on their side due to the differing strategies involved. They might just have to hold their ground and be on the defensive to win, while the other side has to extend into dangerous territory and expose themselves more to the elements of attrition. So even if one has excellent logistics to help avoid an all-out catastrophe, and even if one has a far greater force than the other side, one can still lose to attrition anyway. Things like winter weather and disease can still ravage a force, regardless of supply lines. We saw this for instance in the Crimean war, which saw massive attrition to disease, the horrendous result of which led to much more focus by the Europeans on medical attention being available on future battlefields. The fact that newspapers at the time were beginning to be able to report on battlefield conditions to the rest of the world relatively quickly, probably also spurred this development.

So, applying this to the example of Vietnam, we can see that the gorillas just had to outlast an opponent who was strategically unwilling to escalate the conflict beyond a certain point. This could be seen not as a logistical failure as much as a strategic one, because the goal of winning without escalating beyond a certain point proved impossible, therefore turning the theater into an endless meat grinder. And even if they had battlefield success to report on, that wouldn't change this problem.

Historically, first contacts between racially very different people runs the entire gambit from instant hostility (Philippine natives) to instant hospitality (Tainos), so it seems how they react is mostly cultural. Some people claim that humans are instinctively repulsed or scared by other racially different groups due to evolutionary reasons, but that typically wasn't the case when explorers met isolated tribes, as seen here for example:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WmXQPy3hQYE

Also, wherever foreign groups get to live next to each other, a lot of intermixing tends to happen, self-segregation is quite rare.

>Chien-Shiung Wu (simplified Chinese: 吴健雄; traditional Chinese: 吳健雄; pinyin: Wú Jiànxióng; May 31, 1912 – February 16, 1997) was a Chinese-American experimental physicist who made significant contributions in the field of nuclear physics. Wu worked on the Manhattan Project, where she helped develop the process for separating uranium metal into uranium-235 and uranium-238 isotopes by gaseous diffusion. She is best known for conducting the Wu experiment, which contradicted the hypothetical law of conservation of parity. This discovery resulted in her colleagues Tsung-Dao Lee and Chen-Ning Yang winning the 1957 Nobel Prize in physics, and earned Wu the inaugural Wolf Prize in Physics in 1978. An arrest warrant was put out for Logue and Dorn, but local circuit judge Strom Thurmond, a friend of Sue, was sent out as a negotiator to talk her into surrendering. Fred Dorn, wounded in the shootout, died of his injuries. One officer had been killed instantly in the shootout, the other succumbed two days later. Sue Logue, George Logue, and Clarence Bagwell were convicted of the murders and sentenced to death. All three were executed on January 15, 1943. Joe Logue was also sentenced to die but Governor Olin Johnson commuted his sentence at the last minute to life in prison.

Sue Logue was known in Edgefield County as a tart; stories circulated among local men about the strength of her vaginal muscles. She reportedly had an affair with Strom Thurmond when he was a school superintendant and she had worked as a teacher, and that they'd done the deed in his office at least once. Also when Sue was taken from her cell in Columbia Women's Prison to the electric chair in the state pen, Thurmond accompanied her there and Randall Johnson, a black prison worker and sometimes driver who was manning the prison wagon that day, later claimed he was sure the two had had sex in the back of the vehicle en route to "Old Sparky."

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14399838
>did people in the past had any way to prevent their fruits to go trough this or they just ate them full of worms?

They unironically used pesticide.
People who knew about plants and chemicals would mix up things like dry sulfur, piss, certain abrasive roots & leaves, into a variety of either dried powders you'd dust on the plants or liquids you could paint on them. This one of the ways they'd protect plants. Another option was fumigation, though this one was better for larger pests; you make burning bundles of noxious, toxic, grass and plants, and waft them across your field and grove to drive away the insects.
Finally, some people would just make nets or covers- literally just throw a blanket over your crops, or wrap an apple in a little diaper, to physically stop bugs.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14397906
Saturn/Cronus was a pre-Indoeuropean deity, associated with fertility. He was likely the main god of the pre-Hellenic popuolation of Greece. People continued to venerate him during the Greek period, as evidenced by the festival of Kronia, even though he wasn't the head god anymore because of Greek domination.

Pre-Indoeuropean Europe was mainly agricultural and more egalitarian than later. Kronia was a harvest festival where social hierarchies were temporarily lifted, slaves would become equals with their masters etc. Also, Cronus was thought to be the God ruling over the Golden Age, when supposedly, people (read: the indigenous people who were turned slaves and servants when the Indo-Europeans invaded) were free from hard labor.

Thoughts on Anglicans?

They believe their worship is a continuation of the Roman Catholic Mass, but their understanding of the sacraments is closer to the Reformed. They also say there are only two sacraments: Baptism and Communion. The five lesser rites of the Church are: confirmation, absolution, marriage, holy orders, and anointing of the sick. Anglicans deny the doctrine of transubstantiation, and practice infant baptism.

Anglicans generally accept the definition of Sola Fide as found in Lutheranism and Reformed Protestantism, but reject Sola Scriptura in favor of Prima Scriptura as the writings of the Church Fathers, the Ecumenical Councils, and the Creeds still play an important role in Anglican theology. Anglicans also accept the 66 book Protestant canon of the Holy Bible as scripture but continue to use the 7 books of the deuterocanon as secondary texts, below that of scripture, but still useful for devotional activity.

Anglicans do invoke saints to pray for them, but to a lesser degree than Catholic and Orthodox Christians. Mary is considered the greatest creature of God among Anglicans, the Mother of God, and is venerated highly, considered by most to be a perpetual virgin and without sin, but her immaculate conception and assumption are generally rejected as Papist elaborations.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
As such, Anglicans reject many other Roman Catholic dogmas like purgatory and papal supremacy, but what really distinguishes them from most other Protestants is their continued acceptance of the ministerial priesthood, apostolic succession among bishops, and an episcopal polity. Like Eastern Orthodox, caesaropapism has historically been part of Anglicanism. The Archbishop of Canterbury is first among equals in Anglicanism.

Like in Catholicism, art and statues continue to play a central role in Anglican worship, but to a slightly lesser degree than in Catholicism. So it is not uncommon to come across icons or three dimensional crucifixes in Anglican churches, like in a Catholic church.

Of course like the vast majority of Christians, Anglicans profess the orthodox definition of the Holy Trinity and incarnation of Jesus. But on certain social issues, like the ordination of women, Anglicans do ordain them. Anglicanism is a heavily liturgical tradition just like Catholicism and follows a very similar liturgical calender to seasons like Lent and Advent are celebrated.

Anti-interracial relationship sentiment is the belief that people of different races should not be allowed to form romantic or sexual relationships. This belief is not only deeply harmful and discriminatory, but it is also completely unfounded.

There is no logical reason why people of different races should not be able to form relationships with each other. Love and attraction are not limited by race, and people should be free to form relationships with whomever they choose.

Unfortunately, anti-interracial relationship sentiment has a long and sordid history, and it has often been used as a means of maintaining power and control over marginalized groups. In the United States, for example, interracial relationships were once illegal in many states, and people who engaged in them faced severe punishment. Even today, interracial couples often face discrimination and prejudice from those who hold anti-interracial relationship sentiments.

It is important to recognize and reject this harmful belief. Love and relationships should be based on mutual respect and understanding, not on arbitrary and discriminatory factors such as race. We should strive to create a society that values and celebrates diversity, rather than one that seeks to divide and discriminate against people based on their race or ethnicity.

There are many reasons why we should strive to create a society that values and celebrates diversity, rather than one that seeks to divide and discriminate against people based on their race or ethnicity.

Firstly, diversity is a natural and inherent part of our world. People of different races and ethnicities have always existed and have always contributed to the development and progress of humanity. It is important to recognize and celebrate this diversity, rather than trying to erase or suppress it.

Secondly, diversity brings with it a wealth of knowledge, perspectives, and experiences that can enrich our society and make it stronger. By valuing and celebrating diversity, we can learn from and be inspired by the unique experiences and perspectives of others.

Finally, discrimination and division based on race or ethnicity is deeply harmful and unjust. It creates barriers and divides between people and can lead to suffering and inequality. By striving to create a society that values and celebrates diversity, we can work towards a more just and equal society for all.

Interracial relationships make up an increasingly larger share of the population. Despite this, there exist many racist myths that seek to discourage and even prevent individuals from engaging in interracial relationships. It is important to examine these myths and understand their origin and purpose in order to understand why they continue to exist and how to counteract them. This essay will discuss the racist myths surrounding anti-interracial relationships and how to move away from them. Racist myths surrounding such relationships typically include untrue claims that one race is superior, believing that interracial relationships will lead to the “dilution” of a certain race, and that interracial couples are immoral or have ulterior motives. Through an analysis of the origin, function, and circulation of these myths, it is clear that these ideas are incorrect and based on oppressive stereotypes. This essay will explore the various ways society can work to oppose and debunk these myths in order to create a more inclusive and equitable society.

Many people believe that anti-interracial relationships are actually beneficial for society because they keep people segregated and isolated. However, this is far from the truth when it comes to the impact of anti-interracial relationships. In fact, there is research that shows anti-interracial relationships to be detrimental to a healthy and diverse society. According to author James Jones, "anti-interracial relationships stigmatize mixed backgrounds and lead to stereotypical assumptions about mixed-race individuals that have racist root causes" ("Consequences and Myths of Interracial Relationships"). This implies that anti-interracial relationships can create and perpetuate racism by giving rise to myths, such as the belief that an individual's race determines their intellectual, social, and moral capabilities.

The myths surrounding anti-interracial relationships are perpetuated by the idea that it is beneficial for society to keep people separated and isolated. However, this is not the case, as these relationships can lead to racist behaviour. A common myth is that interracial couples face higher levels of discrimination than couples of the same race. Research has debunked this claim, finding that interracial couples are just as likely to receive negative attention as singles of the same race, if not more so (Waterman & Stillwell, 2018). Other myths suggest that interracial relationships weaken racial identity and lead to a decrease in cultural values. Studies, however, have found that interracial relationships have little to no impact on a person’s racial identification, such as their beliefs or values (Smith et al., 2015). Anti-interracial relationships do not make sense in today’s increasingly diverse and globalised world, and the existence of these myths are decried by many social scientists and advocates.

Many people believe that anti-interracial relationships are beneficial for society because they believe that it keeps people in their own cultural bubbles, and helps to separate the races (Smith). On the other hand, there are those who disagree and feel that anti-interracial relationships can lead to racist behaviour due to a lack of understanding and sensitivity to one another's cultures, customs and lifestyles (Jones). Although separating people through interracial relationships may result in a relatively homogenous population, it also allows for a lack of cultural appreciation and personal growth (Mason). In the end, both sides of the argument have valid points, but ultimately it is up to the individual to decide what is best for themselves and the people they care about.

Interracial relationships have long been stigmatised in American culture, with much of the racism deeply rooted in myths and stereotypes. According to a 2003-2010 US Census Bureau survey, the number of interracial couples has more than tripled since 1967 (U.S. Census Bureau). Despite the increase in interracial relationships, the vast majority of such couples continue to face racism and prejudice. In a report by the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU), four pervasive racist myths surrounding interracial relationships are identified. First, that Black people are biologically less capable of partaking in relationships with people of other races. Second, the belief that interracial relationships damage the gene pool and produce inferior offspring. Third, the idea that people of different races do not share the same cultural values and beliefs. Fourth, the false notion that White people are superior to people of other racial backgrounds (ACLU). Such myths are damaging and misguided, and should be debunked in order to promote equality in relationships and for interracial couples to be able to exist without social stigma or discrimination.

Complex grammar (at least to some minimum standard) has been pretty much universal for millennia, even hunter-gatherers have it. If anything they often have more complex languages; the languages spoken by big settled civilizations are worn down by being learned by a bunch of adults who acquire them imperfectly, while languages of small hunter-gatherer tribes have no such factor keeping them simple. >During the siege of Fort Zeelandia, the Chinese took many Dutch prisoners, among them the Dutch missionary Antonius Hambroek and his wife, and two of their daughters. Koxinga sent Hambroek to Fort Zeelandia to persuade the garrison to surrender; if unsuccessful, Hambroek would be killed upon return. Hambroek went up to the Fort, where two of his other daughters still remained, and urged the garrison to not surrender. He subsequently returned to Koxinga's camp and was beheaded. Additionally, a rumor was spread among the Chinese that the Dutch were encouraging the native Taiwan aboriginals to kill Chinese. In retaliation, Koxinga ordered the mass execution of Dutch male prisoners,[33] mostly by crucifixion and decapitation[34] with a few women and children also being killed. The remainder of the Dutch women and children were enslaved, with Koxinga taking Hambroek's teenage daughter as his concubine (she was described by the Dutch commander Caeuw as "a very sweet and pleasing maiden", while other Dutch women were sold to Chinese soldiers to become their (secondary) wives or mistresses.[35][36][37] The daily journal of the Dutch fort recorded that "the best were preserved for the use of the commanders, and the rest were sold to the common soldiers. Happy was she that fell to the lot of an unmarried man, being thereby freed from vexations by the Chinese women, who are very jealous of their husbands."[38] The Chinese took Dutch women as slave concubines and wives and they were never freed: in 1684 some were reported to be still living. 1. Perpetual Virginity -- the statements regarding Jesus having brothers can be read either way linguistically, there is typology which could apply to Mary, Eze. 44:2, and there is intertexual comparison of Mary with the ark of the covenant in Luke. What we need is a reason to read these things in this way. First we should note what perpetual virginity actually is, which is that Mary was a virgin before, during, and after birth. The "during" means that her virginity remained physically intact as Christ's birth was of a miraculous nature. If this did not occur, then it means that Christ damaged his own mother's physical virginity, which is too impious to consider. This must be avoided, and thus we must at least affirm Mary's virginity during birth. This would fit the typology of Eze. 44:2, and thus also affirm her virginity after birth.

2. Immaculate Conception -- this teaches that Mary was saved by a retroactive application of Christ's saving work: at the moment of her conception she was saved by Christ and preserved from original sin, and cooperated with God's will in committing no personal sins, so that original sin would not pass to Christ. God prepared her as a holy vessel, for if Mary is stained with sin, then that means that God dwelt bodily in a body that was sinful, as his body was within Mary's body, and he took his flesh from Mary's flesh. How can God dwell within a sinful body? Further we know that God is a consuming fire, Heb. 12:29, but this fire burned in Mary's womb and she was not burned -- she is a typological fulfillment of the burning bush -- and she was not consumed because she bore no sin. One should also consider the special love that God has for Mary, for example the icon I have posted which shows God's special relationship to her. Imagine a being which God loves with the special love that a child gives to his mother, and this being raising up God himself as a child. The doctrine is functionally necessary.

From the 1500s to the 1800s, in Eastern Orthodoxy you could purchase indulgences called "Absolution Certificates," in which you would pay a certain amount of money to your bishop and he would issue you a written absolution of sin, for you or someone else, with no repentance required. So you could literally pay to have your sins forgiven.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indulgence#Eastern_Orthodox_Church
https://orthodoxwiki.org/Absolution_Certificates

>These certificates were real indulgences that anyone could obtain which absolved them from sin. These were often obtainable for a specified amounts of money. ... the absolution granted by these certificates had no connection with any participation by the faithful in the Mystery of Penance, nor in the Mystery of the Eucharist.

>Greek Orthodox Patriarch of Jerusalem Dositheos Notaras (1641–1707) wrote: "It is an established custom and ancient tradition, known to all, that the Most Holy Patriarchs give the absolution certificate (συγχωροχάρτιον – synchorochartion) to the faithful people … they have granted them from the beginning and still do."

>The practice of issuing indulgences ... received official confirmation at the Constantinople Council of 1727. ... "The Confession of Faith" from the Council, the text of which was compiled by Patriarch Chrysanthus of Jerusalem and was signed by Patriarchs Paisius II of Constantinople, Sylvester of Antioch, and Chrysanthus of Jerusalem ... said, "The power of the forgiveness of sins, which is termed by the Eastern Church of Christ Absolution Certificates when given in writing, but by the Latins Indulgences, is given to the Holy Church by Christ. These Absolution Certificates are issued in the whole Catholic Church by the four most holy Patriarchs: Constantinople, Alexandria, Antioch, and Jerusalem."

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14400251
The US government didn't support Fischer.
When it comes to what the USSR did for its GMs, it gets a bit more complicated. These players would effectively get a similar deal as Indians GMs do today in that they were employed in various fields on paper but in reality they just focused on chess. What is more important is that the GMs helped each other extensively with prep (normal and legal, but usually not done to the same extent as in the USSR) and traded wins or draws to push certain players to win tournaments (illegal - this is what Fischer had issues with).
However, one interesting thing to point out is that Spassky perhaps wasn't the best example of the Soviet chess meta. Spassky was no doubt a genius, but he was moody and didn't have the same work ethic as people like Botvinnik or Smyslov. Karpov later remarked that Spassky could've had a chance against Fischer had he not been so lazy with his prep.
So in short, the whole thing is overblown, but the basic facts are true.

The Ideological Origins of the American Revolution, awarded both the Pulitzer and the Bancroft prizes, has become a classic of American historical literature. Hailed at its first appearance as “the most brilliant study of the meaning of the Revolution to appear in a generation,” it was enlarged in a second edition to include the nationwide debate on the ratification of the Constitution, hence exploring not only the Founders’ initial hopes and aspirations but also their struggle to implement their ideas in constructing the national government.
>>14391598
Now, in a new preface, Bernard Bailyn reconsiders salient features of the book and isolates the Founders’ profound concern with power. In pamphlets, letters, newspapers, and sermons they returned again and again to the problem of the uses and misuses of power―the great benefits of power when gained and used by popular consent and the political and social devastation when acquired by those who seize it by force or other means and use it for their personal benefit.
>>14391619
This fiftieth anniversary edition will be welcomed by readers familiar with Bailyn’s book, and it will introduce a new generation to a work that remains required reading for anyone seeking to understand the nation’s historical roots.

>>14399182
>Why did he channel all of his hatred towards the industrial revolution while the agricultural revolution(s) are what really set the wheels in motion?
You can't ever prevent agriculture. No matter how far civilization might devolve during a collapse, there will always be plants and seeds and even in some hypothetical scenario where 99% of humans die and the ones that live completely forget how to plant things, it's inevitable that someone will figure it out.

Technological progress, on the other hand, is much more complicated. The industrial revolution required easy access to efficient, concentrated energy sources like coal and oil. It's very possible that if humanity suffers a big enough setback, it would be unable to undergo another industrial revolution because all the easily accessed energy sources have been used. Even if someone had the knowledge of how offshore drilling or fracking works, you can't do it with steam engines.

That's why the focus is on the industrial revolution. If the current technological society can be regressed to a point prior to the industrial revolution, it's very possible that it will never again move past it.

>>14397631
>Why was the spice trade such a big deal?

It was really just "babies first luxury goods market".
The "on brand" spice trade as we know it started during the Roman Empire: Upper Class Romans would buy spice because it had medicinal properties, for flavor, but mostly because it was seen as something expensive and luxurious to own. Well-to-do individuals would cook up a fucking Ostrich or a Peacock or something and cake it in spices to prove what a cool guy they were.
Another major aspect of the spice trade was that nobody who bought spice in Europe actually 'knew' how spice was cultivated, so merchants would just make shit up in order to both vastly inflate the price of their product and to further endear their customer basis to it. Fragrant cinnamon sticks were collected by large carnivorous birds to make their nests and had to be harvested by feeding them large, heavy, slabs of ox meat so when they bring it to their nest it'd fall down and workers could collect it. That kind of thing.

Two other things:
The "food preservation" thing was largely inconsequential to the spice trade. Salt was used for food preservation and it wasn't considered a spice, nor a luxury good, but an economically vital product to harvest, process, and distribute as needed. Also, the people who could afford spices didn't need to preserve their food and the people who ate lots of preserved foods couldn't afford spices.
The second thing is that the spice trade was bankrupting Rome. Romans didn't have any interesting commodities they could easily trade for sacks full of spice, so they were buying it almost exclusively with gold. I think it was Pliny the Elder, but he mentioned how 3 million gold pieces'ish were being siphoned out of Rome, never to be seen again, (and eventually into China) just for spices.
